title: Is metaphysics some advanced philosophy? - Quora

response.answer_text: The word “metaphysics” means literally “beyond the physical”. Metaphysics goes back thousands of years, back at least as far as the ancient Greeks in the West, and similarly around the world. The pre-Socratic philosophers sought to identify substance (literally “that which stands under”), an unchanging reality that went beyond the superficial and changing appearances of the physical world. Plato focused on the soul and the intelligible world of eternal Ideas and Ideals (eidos), beyond the world of the 5 senses. Aristotle called metaphysics the study of being qua being, the nature of being itself. Metaphysics is closely related to ontology, which answers the questions “what is there?”, “what exists?”, “what is real?”. Metaphysics is ancient and foundational. You could even call it “radical” in the literal sense of radix as root, also in the popular sense of radical as shocking and disruptive of the status quo. Therefore, I’m not sure in what sense one might call metaphysics “advanced philosophy”. Popular metaphysics in more recent times dates and derives from the American transcendentalists, e.g. Ralph Waldo Emerson, through revivals and spiritualism of the late 1800s to early 1900s, to the New Thought religions (Unity School of Christianity, Science of Mind, Religious Science) introduced in the early 1900s, to a fascination with Eastern religions and philosophy, many schools of intuitive unfoldment and personal transformation since the mid 1950s, Paul Tillich’s focus on God as “the ground of Being” in mid-20th century, to the revolutionary ideas and culture of the1960s, to “ontological design”-type colloquia, to the current wave of interest in Ascension and multi-dimensional realities and presence. Those are a few highlights that come to mind. Popular metaphysics at what I call the “street” level has been bastardized and watered down in service of ego, reassurances, worldly ambitions, and sensationalism, all of which you can find online, in bookstores, and metaphysical groups worldwide. There are degrees of seriousness and rigor across the different expressions of metaphysics — from the academic and religious, to superficial and cliche’ street metaphysics, and everything in between. The upside to much of street metaphysics is that what its followers lack in academic rigor and spiritual discernment, many of them make up for that in heart and compassion. Ancient metaphysics and popular metaphysics may not look much like each other, but they’re related. Both academic and popular metaphysics are about ultimate reality beyond the physical and the five senses.
